Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: The Effect of Polar Ancestry on Heat Tolerance of the New Zealand Temperate Black Cod

POR.DRECONTENT:
Antarctic waters are dominated by five closely related families of fishes belonging to the perciform suborder Notothenioidei. Following their long isolation at chronic low water temperatures, most now share a marked intolerance to heat. This is most notable in fishes endemic to high-latitude waters where several species have been reported incapable of surviving prolonged exposure to temperatures above 5 to 7 °C when acclimatized to their natural -1.9 °C water temperature. However, it is unknown whether such intolerance would persist were these fishes to come under selection from rising water temperatures.

While most modern notothenioids are restricted to Antarctic waters, several species have continually inhabited warmer temperate waters, and a small number of Antarctic species secondarily returned to temperate water temperatures. The latter are of particular interest, as they presumably once shared the intolerance to heat currently noted among the endemic Antarctic notothenioids while experiencing subsequent selection from more variable water temperatures. New Zealand waters are home to both the continually cold-temperate thornfish (Bovichtus variegatus) and the secondarily temperate black cod (Notothenia angustata). With overlapping geographic and bathymetric distributions these experience similar water temperatures creating a natural system with which to test whether the secondarily temperate black cod continues to lag its presumptive ancestral heat tolerance as measured in the thornfish.

To test this, I determined the heat tolerance of both species as their critical thermal maximum (CTMax) in specimens held at their winter water temperatures (7 -9 °C) and when commonly warm acclimated near summer water temperatures (15 °C). Both species showed significantly higher tolerances than any previously tested Antarctic species, even when those were warm acclimated up to 10 °C. This suggests that the ancestral notothenioids likely had comparable heat tolerance to other cold temperate species prior to their Antarctic radiation, and that the black cod has been able to recover substantial heat tolerance.

However, the secondarily-temperate black cod consistently lagged the CTMax of the thornfish both at their environmental water temperatures and when warm acclimated. This might suggest that the black cod has not fully recovered its presumptive ancestral tolerance despite a lengthy period in warmer water temperatures. If so, the inertia of the heat intolerance found throughout the endemic Antarctic species may impede their ability to adapt to rapid warming.
